meta.title: JAIIB IE&IFS Mock – P1 Module A (Set p1ma2)
meta.topic: Indian Economy & Indian Financial System (Module A: Globalisation, Reforms, FTP, FDI/FII, IMF/World Bank)

questions.question: According to the WTO description cited in the notes, globalisation refers primarily to the movement toward what?
options: Regional self-sufficiency in goods and services
Unrestricted cross-border flows of goods, services, capital, and labour
Bilateral trade under fixed exchange rates
questions.explanation: WTO describes globalisation as movement toward unrestricted cross‑border flows of goods/services, capital and labour.

questions.question: Which organisation popularised the term ‘globalisation’ again in the mid‑1980s?
questions.explanation: The notes state that the OECD popularised the term again in the mid‑1980s.

questions.question: In India, the concept of globalisation was formally introduced with which policy/time period?
questions.explanation: Globalisation was formally introduced in India with the New Economic Policy of 1991–92.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT listed as a main form of protectionism in the notes?
questions.explanation: Protectionism takes three main forms in the notes: tariffs, import quotas, and non‑tariff barriers.

questions.question: Deglobalisation in the notes best refers to:
options: Reducing dependency and integration across global units
Only restricting portfolio flows while allowing trade
Shifting from WTO to regional FTAs
Replacing imports entirely by domestic production
questions.explanation: Deglobalisation is described as reducing dependency and integration among units across the world.

questions.question: Which trio is famously associated with India’s 1991 ‘new economic reforms’?
questions.explanation: The three pillars are Liberalisation, Privatisation and Globalisation (LPG).

questions.question: Narasimham Committee I (1992) led to RBI issuing which key prudential norms?
options: Income recognition, asset classification and provisioning norms
Introduction of Goods and Services Tax
questions.explanation: Post the committee’s report, RBI issued guidelines on income recognition, asset classification and provisioning in Feb 1992.

questions.question: Which is a focus of prudential reforms listed in the notes?
options: Risk‑weighted capital adequacy and mark‑to‑market of investment portfolios
Full interest rate administration by government
questions.explanation: Prudential reforms include risk‑weighted CAR, appropriate accounting norms, and mark‑to‑market for investments.

questions.question: Which supervisory reform was undertaken according to the notes?
options: Creation of Board for Financial Supervision and adoption of CAMELS/risk‑based supervision
Replacing statutory auditors with RBI officers
questions.explanation: The Board for Financial Supervision (BFS), CAMELS ratings, risk‑based and consolidated supervision were introduced.

questions.question: Which technological backbone/system(s) are cited as part of banking technology reforms?
options: INFINET, Negotiated Dealing System (NDS), and RTGS
questions.explanation: Technology reforms include INFINET, NDS for screen‑based G‑Sec trading, and RTGS; alongside ATMs, internet/mobile banking etc.

questions.question: Direct Benefit Transfer (DBT) was initially launched by Government of India on:
questions.explanation: DBT initiation date in the notes is 1 January 2013.

questions.question: Which statement about debt market reforms is correct as per the notes?
options: Government securities pricing remained fully administered
91‑day Treasury Bills were introduced for liquidity management and benchmarking
Repos were abolished and only reverse repos continued
questions.explanation: 91‑day T‑bills were introduced; DvP settlement enhanced transparency; LAF set corridor via repo/reverse repo.

questions.question: Liquidity Adjustment Facility (LAF) in India primarily operates through:
options: Repo and reverse repo auctions to signal overnight rate
questions.explanation: LAF operates via repo and reverse repo auctions to create a corridor for the overnight money market rate.

questions.question: The transition in India’s foreign exchange regime described in the notes is:
options: From floating to fixed exchange rate
From a single‑currency peg to a basket, then to market‑determined floating rate
From gold standard to Bretton Woods system post‑1999
questions.explanation: The notes describe moving from a single‑currency fixed rate to a basket, then to a market‑determined floating rate.

questions.question: Which legislation replaced FERA, 1973 and modernised India’s forex framework?
questions.explanation: FERA, 1973 was replaced by FEMA, 1999.

questions.question: Which set correctly lists participants permitted hedging/derivative use under the forex reforms per notes?
options: Exporters, Indians investing abroad, FIIs/FPIs, etc., subject to underlying exposure
questions.explanation: Participants including exporters, Indians investing abroad and FIIs/NRIs were permitted hedging subject to genuine exposure.

questions.question: The Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority (IRDA) was established following which Act/year?
questions.explanation: The notes state that IRDA was created under the Insurance Regulatory and Development Act, 1999.

questions.question: Which regulator and liberalisation milestone pair for capital markets is correctly matched?
options: SEBI — FIIs permitted since 1992; ADR/GDR/FCCB/ECB access to global capital
questions.explanation: SEBI regulates capital markets; FIIs permitted since 1992; Indian corporates could raise via ADRs/GDRs/FCCBs/ECBs.

questions.question: FTP 2015–20 merged several merchandise incentive schemes into which single scheme?
questions.explanation: Multiple earlier schemes were merged into MEIS; SEIS introduced for services.

questions.question: Under FTP 2015–20/EPCG, when capital goods are procured from domestic manufacturers, what happens to the specific export obligation?
questions.explanation: If capital goods are sourced domestically under EPCG, the specific export obligation was reduced to 75% of normal EO.

questions.question: Which small‑value e‑commerce exports were eligible for MEIS benefits (values up to ₹25,000) as per FTP 2015–20?
options: Handloom, books/periodicals, leather footwear, toys, customised fashion garments
questions.explanation: Notes list specific low‑value e‑commerce exports like handloom, books, leather footwear, toys, customised garments eligible for MEIS.

questions.question: Which pairing of FDI route with example matches the notes?
options: Automatic route — Broadcasting Content Services up to 49%
Automatic route — Medical devices up to 100%
Government route — Thermal power up to 100%
Government route — Only up to 26% in all sectors
questions.explanation: Examples in the notes: Automatic route includes medical devices up to 100% (and thermal power up to 100%); Broadcasting Content Services 49% is under government route.

questions.question: Which sector is listed as PROHIBITED for FDI in India in the notes?
options: Real estate business including construction of farmhouses
questions.explanation: Prohibited list includes lottery, gambling, chit funds, nidhi, TDR trading, real estate business, construction of farmhouses, tobacco manufacturing, atomic energy, core rail operations.

questions.question: The IMF came into operation on which date (as per the notes)?
questions.explanation: IMF came into operation on 27 December 1945; it began financial operations on 1 March 1947; Bretton Woods conference was in 1944.

questions.question: Which statement about Special Drawing Rights (SDR) is correct as per the notes?
options: SDR is a global currency issued by IMF
SDR is an international reserve asset and a potential claim on freely usable currencies
SDR can only be used by private banks for trade finance
SDR requires gold backing to be valid
questions.explanation: SDR is not a currency; it is an international reserve asset that provides a potential claim on freely usable member currencies.
